Novel insights into diethylamine catalytic combustion over CuO catalysts supported by SSZ-13: Undesirable product NOx as a crucial intermediate for N2 generation Xingyue Leng Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Software Visualization Writing – original draft Weiyue Wang Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Lincong He Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Visualization Dandan Li Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Visualization Jian Chen Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Visualization Software Supervision Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Funding acquisition Data curation ⁎ Mengfei Luo Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Zhejiang Normal University, Institute of Physical Chemistry, 688 Yingbin Road, Jinhua 321004, China. Zhejiang Normal University, Institute of Physical Chemistry 688 Yingbin Road Jinhua 321004 China Catalytic combustion of nitrogen-containing volatile organic compounds (NVOCs) could effectively control N2 generation rather than NOx, but its mechanism is still not well answered. Herein, a series of CuO supported by SSZ-13 catalysts (denoted as Cu/S) were prepared for the catalytic combustion of diethylamine (DEA), a typical NVOCs. The effects of CuO loading and calcined temperature of catalysts on the catalytic performance were investigated. Among the Cu/S catalysts, the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst exhibits the highest oxidation activity (lowest T99 of 240 °C), and widest temperature window (△T = 120 °C) for high N2 selectivity (>99%). This result is ascribed to its highest ratio of easily reduced CuO active species. Importantly, there are two important steps for DEA combustion (I: catalytic oxidation to NOx; II: selective catalytic reduction of NOx with DEA to N2). Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with DEA is the very crucial pathway for N2 generation. The easily reduced CuO species play crucial roles on both catalytic oxidation and selective catalytic reduction. In addition, water vapor (5 vol.%) slightly improved oxidation activity of DEA, and increased N2 selectivity at high temperature (>350 °C), but the catalytic oxidation activity of intermediate CO was decreased caused by the competitive adsorption of water vapor. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic combustion CuO catalysts Oxidation activity Selective catalytic reduction N2 selectivity 1 Introduction It is well known that air pollution caused by volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission has drawn more and more our attentions up to date [1–5]. Particularly, the nitrogen-containing volatile organic compounds (NVOCs) with low boiling point are very hazardous for us, such as the organic compounds containing groups NH2 (primary amine), NH (secondary amine), N (tertiary amine), CONH (amide), CN (cyano), NO2 (nitro), and so forth [6–12]. Whereas, a large amount of NVOCs emission are widely present in petrochemical, pharmaceutical and leather production industries, e.g. the process of DMF distillation recovery. Therefore, the elimination of NVOCs emission is in an urgent need. There are numerous methods for the NVOCs elimination including adsorption, thermal combustion and catalytic combustion, etc. [13,14]. For instance, the traditional thermal combustion should be a convenient method which have been widely employed in application such as regenerative thermal oxidizer (RTO). But the N element in NVOCs will be easily transformed into NOx due to the high operating temperature, which are unexpected products and also very hazardous to environment. Thus, the addition of subsequent selective catalytic reduction (SCR) denitration process is demanded to eliminate NOx, which increases the cost and complexity of NVOCs elimination process. However, the catalytic combustion could be conducted at relatively low temperature and completely convert the NVOCs into harmless molecular H2O, N2 and CO2 [15,16]. Therefore, catalytic combustion is considered one of the most effective methods for eliminating NVOCs, such as regenerative catalytic oxidation (RCO). The efficiency of catalytic combustion for NVOCs elimination mainly depends on the catalyst. Nowadays, the catalysts employed to NVOCs combustion includes precious metal oxides catalysts (Ag2O, PtOx, RuOx) and transition metal oxides catalysts (CuO, MnOx, etc.) [17,18]. Precious metal oxides catalysts have been widely used in the filed of catalytic combustion because of their high catalytic oxidation activity, such as for the combustion of alkanes, esters, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, etc. But the undesirable products NOx will generate on the precious metal catalysts, which may be ascribed to their high catalytic oxidation activity. Ma et al. investigated the n-butylamine combustion over the spherical-like Pd/SiO2 catalysts, Pd/S-2GA prepared by grafting method possessed the highest Pd dispersion and catalytic oxidation activity (T90=234 °C), but it also exhibited the lowest N2 selectivity [19]. Zhang et al. used the 3d transition metal (Cu, Co, Fe, V, Mn) and precious metal (Pd, Ag, Pt) catalysts for the combustion of acetonitrile, the catalytic oxidation activity was in order: Pt>Pd>Cu>Co>Fe>V>Ag>Mn, but the lowest N2 selectivity was obtained over the Pt and Pd catalysts [20]. Compared with precious metal catalysts, the transition metal catalysts could give higher N2 selectivity, which may be related to their relatively low oxidation activity. Lu et al. found that the 20MnOx/ZSM-5(18) could exhibit the high catalytic oxidation (with T98 of 240 °C) and the high N2 selectivity in a wide temperature window (△T = 180 °C) for DEA combustion [21]. Moreover, the transition metal catalysts (such as CuO, MnOx) also have the advantage of low price, which are considered as the most promising catalysts for NVOCs combustion. Besides the metal oxides active compounds, the supports property (e.g. surface acidity) also significantly affect the N2 selectivity. Commonly, the zeolites supports with abundant acid sites (such as ZSM-5) could give excellent catalytic performance for NVOCs combustion [22]. For instance, our group investigated the CuO catalyst supported by ZSM-5 with different Si/Al (18, 60, 130 and 360) for DEA combustion, the catalyst supported by ZSM-5 with Si/Al of 18 obviously exhibited the highest N2 selectivity due to its abundant medium strong and strong acid density [23]. Xing et al. adopted a series of zeolites (ZSM-5, MOR, MCM-22, Hβ and SAPO-34) supported CuO catalysts for n-butylamine combustion, the catalyst supported by ZSM-5 possessed the highest oxidation activity and N2 selectivity [24]. Liu et al. investigated the acrylonitrile catalytic combustion over Cu/ZSM-5, Cu/Beta, Cu/MCM-22, Cu/MCM-49 and Cu/Y catalysts, and the N2 selectivity was in order: Cu-ZSM-5(SiO2/Al2O3=26)>Cu-MCM-49> Cu-MCM-22 > Cu-Beta > Cu-Y [25]. Much progress has been made in the filed of NVOCs combustion, but it is still very challenging to clarify the reaction pathway (especially for N2 generation) and deepen the temperature window for high N2 selectivity. SSZ-13 zeolite with abundant acid sites are commonly used in SCR reaction for NOx elimination [26,27], but there are rarely works about SSZ-13 zeolite applied in NVOCs combustion. Herein, we have designed a series of CuO catalyst supported by SSZ-13 zeolite for the catalytic combustion of diethylamine. The effects of CuO loading and calcined temperature have been investigated, and the possible reaction pathway of N2 generation for DEA oxidation combustion was proposed. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Chemical and reagents SSZ-13 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 20) was purchased from Catalyst Plant of Nankai University. Reagents of Cu(NO3)2•3H2O and liquid diethylamine were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, China. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst Firstly, a certain amount of Cu(NO3)2•3H2O was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water. Then, the zeolite support (SSZ-13, 1 g) was dispersed into the Cu(NO3)2 solution above and kept stirring for 8 h at room temperature. Afterwards, the mixture solution was evaporated to dryness at 90 °C on a water bath. Subsequently, the obtained solid was put into oven at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at desired temperature with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in static air for 5 h. The prepared catalysts were designated as xCu/S-y, in which x (x = 0, 2, 6, 10, 14) and y (y = 18, 60, 130, 360) represent the content of Cu and calcination temperature, respectively. 2.3 Characterization methods X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded by using a Bruker's D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation, working at 40 kV and 40 mA. The patterns were collected in the 2θ range from 10 to 90° with a scanning rate of 0.15° s−1. The reducibility of the catalyst was determined by the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment in a fixed-bed reactor equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The surface acidity of the catalysts was measured by the temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) under a fixed-bed reactor equipped with a gas chromatography equipped with TCD detector. The detailed experiment process were described in our previous works [21,23]. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) for analyzing surface Cu species was conducted on a Thermo Fischer ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with an Al Kα (15 kV, 10.8 mA, hv = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation light source under ca. 2 × 10−7 Pa ultrahigh vacuum, calibrated internally by the adventitious carbon Si2p (Eb = 103.4 eV). 2.4 Evaluation of catalytic performance The oxidation activity of catalysts for DEA combustion was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (i.d. = 8 mm) with 1 mL catalyst (20–40 mesh, 0.45 g) at atmospheric pressure. A air flow of 5 mL/min went through a liquid DEA bottle at 0 °C, and then this flow with saturated DEA vapor was diluted by dry a air flow of 300 mL/min. The dry mixed reaction gas containing ca. 4200 mg m−3 DEA was inlet to fixed-bed with a mass space velocity (S.V.) of 20, 000 mL g−1 h−1. In order to investigate water vapor effect, the air flow of 300 mL/min went through the water bottle at 33 °C and then mixed with the saturated DEA vapor flow (5 mL/min), the reaction gas containing ca. 4200 mg m−3 DEA and 5 vol.% water vapor was inlet into fixed-bed with the same mass space velocity to dry condition. The inlet ([C]in) and outlet ([C]out) DEA vapor concentrations were analyzed by an online gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an SH-Stabliwax-DB capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm). The conversion of DEA can be calculated by the following equation: Conversion = ( [ C ] i n − − [ C ] o u t ) / [ C ] i n × 100 % . where [C]in and [C]out are DEA concentrations in the inlet and outlet gas, respectively. NOx and CO are analyzed by flue gas analyzer (ecom-EN3, ECOM, Germany), no NH3 is detected. The selectivity of N2 is calculated by following equation: Selectivity ( N 2 ) = ( 1 − actual NOx yield theoretical NOx yield ) × 100 % Simultaneously, the selectivity of CO is also calculated by the ratio of actual CO concentration and theoretical CO concentration. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for DEA oxidation Fig. 1 gives the catalytic performance of CuO/S-450 catalysts for DEA oxidation. The selectivity of N2 and CO at certain temperature, and the temperature window (△T) for high selectivity of N2 (>99%) after T99 are listed in Table 1 . The temperature window (△T) represents the performance for controlling the N2 generation, namely, wider temperature window (△T) indicates the better performance. SSZ-13 exhibits high T99 for DEA oxidation (>400 °C), and high CO selectivity (such as 18% of CO selectivity at 400 °C) (Fig. 1a and Table 1), implying the lack of oxidation active sites. The oxidation activity could be remarkably enhanced after CuO addition (T99 of 2CuO/S-450 is 280 °C for DEA oxidation). And the oxidation activity could be continuously increased when the loading of CuO increased to 10 wt.% (10CuO/S-450 with T99 of only 240 °C). However, it can be found that the oxidation activity of 20CuO/S-450 catalyst (with T99 of 260 °C) was lower than the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. Wang et al. also found that too high CuO content in CuW/CeZr catalyst was unfavorable to catalytic activity due to the aggregation of CuO species.28 In addition, the pure CuO physically mixed with quartz sand also exhibited lower oxidation activity than 10CuO/S-450 catalyst, illustrating that the dispersed CuO species on SSZ-13 play crucial roles on the catalytic oxidation. Besides the catalytic oxidation activity, the N2 selectivity is also an important aspect for DEA oxidation. It can be seen that the catalytic oxidation of DEA over pure CuO catalyst (dark line) gives very low N2 selectivity (Fig. 1c). Whereas the SSZ-13 could exhibit higher N2 selectivity even with lower catalytic oxidation activity compared to CuO catalyst. Therefore, it can be concluded that CuO active species are crucial for the oxidation activity, and the acid SSZ-13 support plays important roles on the N2 selectivity. Furthermore, the N2 selectivity would firstly increase and then decrease for all the CuO/S-450 catalysts when the reaction temperature increases, which will be discussed in following (the part involving the reaction pathway). Apart from the above discussion on oxidation activity and N2 selectivity at certain temperature, the wide temperature window (△T) for high N2 selectivity (and low CO selectivity) after T99 is also demanded for actual application. Although SSZ-13 could give the relatively high N2 selectivity in the tested temperature range (Fig. 1a), its oxidation activity is too low (T99 > 400 °C, and high CO selectivity). Thus, the temperature window (△T) of SSZ-13 for high N2 selectivity (>99%) after T99 is 0 °C in the tested temperature range (Table 1). 2CuO/S-450 catalyst shows higher oxidation activity compared to SSZ-13, but the oxidation activity is still not enough because of the high CO selectivity (> 12%) in the temperature range from 280 °C to 320 °C. Thus, even the 2CuO/S-450 catalyst gives the wide temperature window (△T = 120 °C) for high N2 selectivity, which is still imperfect due to its high CO selectivity. The widest temperature window (△T = 120 °C) for high N2 selectivity (> 99%) and relative low CO selectivity is obtained on 10CuO/S-450 catalyst when the CuO loading increases to 10 wt.%. However, 20CuO/S-450 catalyst shows the narrower temperature window (△T) of 80 °C when the CuO loading further increases to 20 wt.%. The effect of calcined temperature of 10CuO/S catalyst on catalytic performance was also discussed for DEA oxidation (Fig. 2). Firstly, the oxidation activity firstly increased and then decreased when the calcined temperature was increased from 350 to 650 °C. Among them, 10CuO/S-450 catalyst prepared at 450 °C exhibited the highest oxidation activity, which gave the lowest T99 of 240 °C (Table 2 ). Secondly, the N2 selectivity would also be found to firstly increase and then decrease for all the 10CuO/S catalysts when the reaction temperature increase from 200 to 400 °C. In addition, the N2 selectivity decreased more seriously for 10CuO/S catalyst prepared at higher temperature when the reaction temperature was beyond 340 °C. Furthermore, 10CuO/S-450 catalyst could exhibit very robust stability for DEA oxidation at 280 °C the conversion of DEA and N2 selectivity remain at 100% even after 60 h (Fig. 2c and d). The effect of calcined temperature of 10CuO/S catalyst on temperature window (△T) was also evaluated in Table 2. It can be seen that the temperature window (△T) increases from 60 to 120 °C when the calcined temperature increases from 350 to 450 °C. However, the temperature window (△T) would decrease when the calcined temperature is continuously increased to 550 and 650 °C. Thus, 10CuO/S-450 catalyst prepared at 450 °C gave the widest temperature window for high N2 selectivity. It can be seen that the factor of calcined temperature not only adjusts the catalytic oxidation activity but also significantly affects the N2 selectivity, which may be closely related to the chemical state of CuO species. Therefore, the detailed characterizations of CuO catalysts are given and discussed in following. 3.2 Structural and physicochemical properties of catalysts Fig. 3 gives the XRD patterns of CuO/S catalysts, and the SEM and TEM images of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. The characteristic diffraction peaks of SSZ-13 zeolite could be easily observed for all the CuO/S catalysts. In addition, the intensity of diffraction peaks at 35.5° and 38.7° gradually increase when the loading of CuO increases (Fig. 3a), which are attributed to the CuO crystalline phase (PDF No. 48–1548). This result implies the presence of crystalline CuO species on the SSZ-13 support surface. For all the 10CuO/S catalyst prepared under different temperature, the characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO species could also be observed. From the SEM and TEM images of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst (Fig. 3c and d, Figure S1), there is no characteristic morphology of CuO active species supported on SSZ-13 surface. The CuO active species possess different size in CuO/S catalyst, the large size is 20–30 nm whereas the small size is less than 10 nm (Fig. 3d). Moreover, it could be inferred that the partial CuO species with small size are in internal pores of SSZ-13 and some pores of support SSZ-13 are blocked by the CuO species, resulting in the dramatic decrease of surface area (551 m2/g of SSZ-13 vs 384 m2/g of 10CuO/S-450). XRF result implies that the actual CuO content in 10CuO/S catalyst is close to theoretical value such as 9.3 wt.% for 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. And the element mapping images indicates the uniformly distributed Cu element on the SSZ-13 (Figure S2). Moreover, the sizes of CuO nanoparticle were calculated by the Scherrer formula (Table 3 ). It can be seen that the sizes of CuO nanoparticle gradually increased from 20.1 to 31.0 nm when the CuO loading increased from 2 to 10 wt.% in catalyst. The sizes of CuO nanoparticle obtained by XRD (31.0 nm) is close to the large size of CuO observed in TEM image (20–30 nm) for 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. However, the sizes of CuO nanoparticle would only sightly increased when the loading of CuO increased from 10 to 20 wt.% (from 31.0 to 32.0 nm). And the CuO nanoparticles sizes were also affected by the calcined temperature. For 10CuO/S catalysts, the sizes of CuO particles increased from 28.3 to 35.3 nm when the calcined temperature was increased from 350 to 650 °C. Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of CuO/S catalysts. It can be seen that there are two kinds of CuO species in 2CuO/S-450 and 10CuO/S-450 (Fig. 4a), the reduction peak α at 250 °C can be ascribed to the easily reduced CuO species, whereas the reduction peak β at 380 °C is corresponding to the difficultly reduced CuO species. However, a new reduction peak β’ can be observed at 350 °C for 20CuO/S-450 catalyst, which is related to presence the CuO species with medium reducibility. In addition, the total reduction peak areas increase for CuO/S-450 catalysts when the loading of CuO increases, implying the increasing hydrogen consumption for more CuO reduction. As for 10CuO/S catalysts prepared at different temperature, it can be found that there are also three reduction peaks (α, β’ and β) in 10CuO/S-350 catalyst. And the intensity of reduction peak α significantly increases whereas the reduction peak β’ disappears for 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. The area ratio of reduction peak α gradually decreases for 10CuO/S catalyst when the calcined temperature continuously increases from 450 °C to 650 °C. Thus, it can be found that the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst possesses the highest ratio of easily reduced CuO species. Fig. 5 shows the XPS spectra of Cu 2p CuO/S catalysts. The peaks with binding energies in the range of 930–940 and 950–960 eV can be attributed to Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 of CuO species, respectively. There are also two satellite peaks of CuO observed in the range of 941–945 and 960–965 eV. Moreover, the signals of Cu 2p3/2 can be fitted to the peaks with binding energies of 935.9 and 933.6 eV which are attributed to α and β CuO species, respectively. The signals of Cu 2p1/2 can also be fitted to the peaks with binding energies of 955.4 and 953.1 eV which are attributed to α and β CuO species, respectively. The α CuO species are corresponding to the highly dispersed CuO combined with oxygen atoms on the zeolite surface [23], which are easily to be reduced (the α reduction peak in H2-TPR). Whereas, the β CuO species are corresponding to CuO particles with larger size and would be reduced at relative higher temperature (the β and β’ peaks in H2-TPR). In addition, it can be found that 10CuO/S-450 catalyst gives the highest peak area ratio of α/β (0.53) according to fitting result of α and β peak area among all the CuO/S catalysts. This observation is consistent with the H2-TPR result that 10CuO/S-450 catalyst possesses the highest ratio of α CuO species (Fig. 4). Fig. 6 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of CuO/S catalysts. It can be seen that there are different NH3 desorption peaks observed for CuO/S catalysts in the temperature of 100 to 680 °C, implying the existence of different kinds acid sites in the CuO/S catalysts. For the CuO/S-450 catalysts with different CuO loading (Fig. 6a), the peak α should be ascribed to the NH3 desorption from the weak acid sites, while the peak β is corresponding to the existence of medium strong acid sites. It is interesting to find that a new peak γ is observed when the CuO loading is increased from 2 to 10 wt.%, indicating the formation of strong acid sites. In addition, the intensity of both peaks β and γ increases when the CuO loading increases to 20 wt.%, which represents the further increase of the amount medium strong and strong acid sites in 20CuO/S-450 catalyst. This observation may be ascribed to the increased amount of Cu2+ in catalyst because of its Lewis acid property. Hu et al. also found the increase of CuO loading also led to the generation of strong acid sties in the CuO/ZSM-5–18 catalyst [23]. For 10CuO/S catalysts prepared at different temperature, there are also three NH3 desorption peaks (α, β and γ) similar to 10CuO/S-450 catalyst due to the presence of different kinds of acid sites in catalysts. The 10CuO/S-350 prepared at low temperature gives high intensity of NH3 desorption peaks (β and γ) which can be attributed to the existence of more Cu2+ species. 3.3 The proposed reaction pathway over 10CuO/S-450 catalyst In order to understand the reaction pathway of DEA oxidation over 10CuO/S-450 catalyst, the reaction was conducted with the controlled amount of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst (0.2 mL; 0.2 + 0.2 mL; 0.2 + 0.8 mL) as shown in Fig. 7. The conversion of DEA is only 32.4% obtained with 0.2 mL 10CuO/S-450 catalyst at 280 °C, the selectivity of N2 and NOx is 93% and 7%, respectively. The byproduct CO is observed which could be considered as one of the intermediates for the complete oxidation of DEA, and the CO selectivity is high to 9.5% due to the lack of active sites. According to the catalytic performance and characterization results (Table 1, Figs. 4 and 5), the easily reduced CuO species are the important active sites for CO oxidation since 10CuO/S-450 catalyst gives the lowest CO selectivity. The DEA conversion could be increased to 75.5% at 280 °C when the amount of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst increased (0.2 mL + 0.2 mL). Interestingly, the NOx selectivity decreases from 7% to 2%, and the N2 selectivity increases from 93% to 99%. It is easy to understand the increase of DEA conversion and the decrease of CO selectivity (from 9.5 to 8.7%) when the amount of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst is increased. However, why does the NOx produced in front layer decrease in the out gas? Furthermore, the DEA conversion could increase to 100% and CO selectivity could decrease to 2.2% at 280 °C when the amount of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst is continuously increased (0.2 + 0.8 mL). The NOx selectivity decreases to 0% and the N2 selectivity increase to 100%. There are no NOx and intermediate CO products observed when the reaction temperature further increase to 300 °C for 1 mL catalyst bed layer. For answering the above question, the reaction pathway of DEA oxidation, especially for N2 generation, is proposed as shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, DEA oxidation reaction was proceeded over 10CuO/S-450 catalyst, and the oxidation products (NOx, CO, CO2 and H2O) were obtained. Secondly, the reduction of NOx by CO is considered to be very difficult due to the usage of non-noble metal catalyst (CuO) and the presence of high O2 (ca. 20%) [28, 29], it can be inferred that the undesirable oxidation product NOx would react with DEA to produce the target product N2 through a similar SCR, including the further oxidation of hydrocarbon species and CO to H2O and CO2. Thus, the NOx selectivity could decrease from 7% to 2% when the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst was increased (from 0. 2 mL to 0.2 + 0.2 mL) at 280 °C, and no NOx product would be observed as the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst was further increased (0.2 + 0.8 mL) at 280 °C. There are also some previous work about similar SCR for NOx reduced by organic amine or amino group (-NH, -NH2) to N2. For instance, Xing et al. reported that the catalytic degradation of n-butylamine could be achieved by reacting with low concentration NO over Cu0.4Mg2.6AlO catalyst, and environmental friendly product N2 was obtained [30]. This result also confirmed that the selective catalytic reduction could take place between NOx and organic amines. Zhang et al. pointed out that the catalytic reduction of NO or HNO species by -NH2 or -NH species was an important pathway to generate N2 for catalytic oxidation of NH3 over RuOx/TiO2 [31]. The SCR may be not the only pathway but at least an important one for the generation of N2 in the DEA oxidation reaction. In other words, the undesirable products NOx play an important role as an intermediate for the generation of N2. Importantly, only the reaction rate of SCR is fast or at least matches to the catalytic oxidation reaction, no NOx products would be obtained (namely, N2 selectivity of 100%). As shown in Figs. 1b and 2b, the N2 selectivity gradually increased at low temperature range (< 250 °C), which was attributed to the increased activity of SCR and the gradually eliminated difference between the oxidation activity and SCR activity when the reaction temperature was increased. In the temperature window with high N2 selectivity (>99%), the reaction rate of SCR matches to the catalytic oxidation reaction and no NOx product is observed. However, the product of NOx would remarkably increase when the reaction temperature is increased beyond the highest temperature of temperature window (△T). This observation can be explained by that the rate of oxidation reaction was accelerated faster than that of the SCR reaction, and the excess NOx would be observed at the outlet of reactor. 3.4 Brief discussion of catalytic performance with catalyst properties According to the discussions above, it can be found that the amount of CuO species and calcined temperature significantly affects the catalytic oxidation activity for DEA oxidation, and the acid support SSZ-13 is the key factor for high N2 selectivity due to its abundant acid sites. However, the question still needing to be answered is that why 10CuO/S-450 catalyst could give the widest temperature window for high N2 selectivity. It can be found there is only slight difference in CuO size between the 10CuO/S-450 and 20CuO/S-450, or 10CuO/S catalysts prepared at different temperature (Table 3), which exhibit very different temperature window for high N2 selectivity. Thus, the size of CuO species may be not the crucial effects on the N2 selectivity in this system. In addition, the NH3-TPD profile of 10CuO/S-450 is similar to that of the 10CuO/S-550 (Fig. 6b), implying that the equivalent acidity to each other; whereas the temperature window of 10CuO/S-450 (△T = 120 °C) is much wider than that of 10CuO/S-550 (△T = 60 °C) for high N2 selectivity. Moreover, it can be seen that the acidity of 10CuO/S-650 is obviously higher than 10CuO/S-450 based on the NH3-TPD profile (Fig. 6b), but the later shows wider temperature window. Thus, it seems to that there is still other dominant factor which also remarkably affects the N2 selectivity besides the acidity of catalyst. It can be seen that there is significant difference of CuO species ratio (α and β in XPS) in CuO/S catalysts (Fig. 5). And the 10CuO/S-450 shows the highest ratio of α CuO specie (0.53) among the CuO/S catalysts with different CuO loading or prepared at different temperature, and the α CuO species correspond to that easily reduced in H2-TPR (α reduction peak). Our previous work demonstrated the easily reduced α CuO species were active sites for catalytic oxidation [23], which is responsible for the highest catalytic oxidation activity of 10CuO/S-450. Furthermore, it can be also inferred that the α CuO species in CuO/S catalysts could also play crucial roles on the selective catalytic reduction for NOx with DEA, which leads to the widest temperature window of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst for high N2 selectivity. Conversely, both 20CuO/S-450 (0.46) and 10CuO/S-350 (0.43) with low ratio of α CuO species exhibit narrower temperature window compared to 10CuO/S-450. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that the α CuO species could not only promote the catalytic oxidation activity but also accelerate the selective catalytic reduction of NOx, which result in the lowest T99 (240 °C) and widest temperature window (△T = 120 °C) obtained on 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. 3.5 The effect of water vapor on the catalytic performance Generally, there is water vapor co-existing with the VOCs in the real exhaust condition. Therefore, the effect of water vapor (5 vol.%) on the catalytic performance of DEA oxidation was also investigated over the optimal catalyst 10CuO/S-450. It can be seen that water vapor (5 vol.%) slightly promotes the DEA oxidation over 10CuO/S-450 (Fig. 8 a). Interestingly, the existence of water vapor decreased the N2 selectivity in low temperature range (<250 °C) but enhanced the N2 selectivity in high temperature range (>350 °C) (Fig. 8b). This observation may be ascribed to that the water vapor slightly enhances the oxidation activity of DEA and more NOx products are generated at low temperature range (<250 °C). And the subsequent SRC could not deplete the large amount of NOx products immediately, leading to the decrease of N2 selectivity. Whereas, the presence of water vapor could promote the SRC which results in the increase of N2 selectivity in high temperature range (>350 °C). Liu et al. also found that the water vapor remarkably promoted the ammonia selective catalytic reduction over copper-exchanged LTA zeolites and they proposed that water might be beneficial for nitrogen oxides removal by tuning the active sites and reaction pathways over metal-containing zeolites [32]. In addition, it can be seen that the presence of water vapor (5 vol.%) would not be beneficial for the oxidation of the intermediate CO in the all temperature range (Fig. 8c), which could be ascribed to the competitive adsorption of H2O and CO on active sites [33,34]. The oxidation reactions of DEA (slightly increased activity) and intermediate CO (decreased activity) exhibit very different activity behaviors in presence of water vapor, illustrating the weaker competitive adsorption effect of water vapor with DEA on active than that of intermediate CO. This suppose is reasonable because the organic amines molecular commonly exhibit strong adsorption on catalyst surface. 4 Conclusion In summary, CuO catalysts supported by SSZ-13 (CuO/S) were prepared for DEA catalytic combustion. The CuO loading and calcined temperature significantly affected the catalytic oxidation activity and N2 selectivity. The highest catalytic oxidation activity (lowest T99 of 240 °C) and widest temperature window (△T = 120 °C) for high N2 selectivity (>99%) were observed on 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. Furthermore, it can be found that there should be two steps (step I: catalytic oxidation to NOx; step II: SCR of NOx with DEA) for DEA oxidation. The SCR of NOx with DEA may be the very crucial pathway for N2 generation in DEA oxidation. The CuO species with high reducibility are favorable for enhancing the catalytic oxidation activity and improving the SCR, resulting in the high catalytic activity and wide temperature window of 10CuO/S-450 catalyst. The existence of water vapor could slightly increase the catalytic oxidation activity DEA but are not beneficial for the oxidation of intermediate CO due to the competitive adsorption of water vapor. And it is interesting to find that water vapor could enhance the N2 selectivity at high temperature (>350 °C). coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion of nitrogen-containing volatile organic compounds (NVOCs) could effectively control N2 generation rather than NOx, but its mechanism is still not well answered. Herein, a series of CuO supported by SSZ-13 catalysts (denoted as Cu/S) were prepared for the catalytic combustion of diethylamine (DEA), a typical NVOCs. The effects of CuO loading and calcined temperature of catalysts on the catalytic performance were investigated. Among the Cu/S catalysts, the 10CuO/S-450 catalyst exhibits the highest oxidation activity (lowest T99 of 240 °C), and widest temperature window (△T = 120 °C) for high N2 selectivity (>99%). This result is ascribed to its highest ratio of easily reduced CuO active species. Importantly, there are two important steps for DEA combustion (I: catalytic oxidation to NOx; II: selective catalytic reduction of NOx with DEA to N2). Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with DEA is the very crucial pathway for N2 generation. The easily reduced CuO species play crucial roles on both catalytic oxidation and selective catalytic reduction. In addition, water vapor (5 vol.%) slightly improved oxidation activity of DEA, and increased N2 selectivity at high temperature (>350 °C), but the catalytic oxidation activity of intermediate CO was decreased caused by the competitive adsorption of water vapor.
coredata.dc:title: Novel insights into diethylamine catalytic combustion over CuO catalysts supported by SSZ-13: Undesirable product NOx as a crucial intermediate for N2 generation
